awd_titl_txt: ABI Innovation: Novel Methodology for Leveraging Metabolic Simulation to Improve Regulatory Reconstruction
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to Rochester Institute of Technology is to develop novel computational methods to better reconstruct gene regulatory networks using metabolic simulation. Accurate prediction of the behavior of gene regulatory networks is necessary to advance areas such as biotechnology, drug development, and whole cell modeling, and the integration of prior biological knowledge about regulatory structure and/or behavior is critical for successful predictions. However, using prior metabolic knowledge is challenging, as it is indirect and can only be evaluated using metabolic simulation. In this project, the team is developing computational methods that will allow the metabolic prior to be integrated into the regulatory network reconstruction. 

The advances made in this study will improve the accuracy of gene regulatory network reconstruction, and will help to determine to what degree integration of metabolic models can improve regulatory network reconstruction. The interdisciplinary research team combines expertise in large-scale computationally intensive statistical modeling and molecular biology, and is well equipped to assure the validity, tractability and statistical soundness of the work. Several students will be trained in the activities, representatives from underrepresented groups will be included, and the outcomes will include software tools that are freely available to the research community.

por.por_cntn:
Research in constructing and evaluating gene networks, which are collections of interacting genes, gene products, and other molecular regulators, is of high significance because these networks control development, differentiation, environmental response, and disease. It is challenging because of the large number of heterogeneous interacting elements, potential combinations of these elements,and the changing states of networks dependent on cellular context.  Advances in high-throughput experimental measurement of molecular components and in computational methods in machine learning and modeling together have led to new approaches in network reconstruction.  Our project aimed to develop novel computational methods for the reconstruction of gene regulatory networks by combining gene expression data with other forms of biological information, including metabolic pathways. Using statistical models of gene expression, as a function of experimental conditions, to predict network interactions, we explored whether metabolic information could improve predictions.  Whereas uncovering variations in gene regulatory interactions across experiments provided key information for robustly predicting gene network structures there was no statistically significant improvement in prediction accuracy after combining the metabolic information primarily due to the small percentage of metabolic genes in the datasets. We also studied whether different types of biological information (metabolic pathways, transcription factor-gene interactions, gene ontology relationships, among others) improve machine learning outcomes using embedding methods. We have created GNE, a scalable deep learning framework to unify known gene interactions and gene expression to learn low-dimensional representations that encode the topological properties and expression similarity. We compared the predictive power of our approach to the state-of-the-art machine learning methods and demonstrate GNE's substantial improvement in predicting gene interactions.  We also demonstrated that novel gene interaction predictions in E. coli and yeast could be validated by updated literature-based database entries. Protein-protein interaction (PPI) data was next used with the goal of learning informative and interpretable representations of the proteins from their amino acid sequences. Our novel embedding framework allowed us to identify amino acids that are important biological motifs because it learns to identify the interface residues of the protein that contact with residues from the interacting proteins.  This research was applied to yeast data and also extended to human PPI data. Future work will continue to investigate additional multi-omics data and how they might improve protein-protein or other gene regulatory interactions that contribute to gene networks. These findings have been disseminated in national and international conferences and journals. Software and code is shared within the open source repository, GitHub. Broader Impacts of this project include engagement and training of undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary research and participation of students from underrepresented groups.
